body: I can confirm that the bug still exists with 0.12.0

issue.title: [BUG] `Differencer` in `ForecastingPipeline` and `TransformedTargetForecaster` does not work!

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/discussions/2451
Originally posted by **anthonygiorgio97** April 13, 2022 I was trying to do a Pipeline with transformers for both exogenous X (4 features) and endogenous y variable with a FeatureSelection(), a LogTransformer() and a Differencer() combined with a cross validation to tune Prophet (but the same happen with other algorithms). The difference operator must exclude the first index from both exogenous and endogenous variable (because I have specified this transformation both in ForecastingPipeline and TransformedTargetForecaster), but when I call the fit method this error raise: (time) indices of series 0 are not contained in index of series 0, extra indices are: DatetimeIndex(['2016-01-31'], dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None) where 2016-01-31 is the first index. If I use a classic Detrender() the code work, but I want to try with the Differencer() operator. I am using sktime 0.11.0. This is the code I am using: ```python pipe_prophet = ForecastingPipeline(steps=[ ("selection", FeatureSelection(method = 'columns')), ("logX", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())), ("differencerX", Differencer()), ("prophetforecaster", TransformedTargetForecaster(steps = [ ("log", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())), ("differencer", Differencer()), ("prophet", Prophet(yearly_seasonality='auto')) ])) ]) cv = ExpandingWindowSplitter(initial_window = len(train_model) - (N_cv_fold - 1) * step_cv - len(fh), start_with_window = True, step_length = step_cv, fh = list(range(1,forecasting_horizon +1,1))) param_grid = [{"logX__passthrough": [False], "prophetforecaster__log__passthrough": [False], "selection__columns": [[prod_group + ' ADJ'],[prod_group + ' ADJ','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MEAN'],[prod_group + ' ADJ','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MEAN','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MIN','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MAX']], "prophetforecaster__prophet__seasonality_mode": ['additive','multiplicative'], "prophetforecaster__prophet__add_country_holidays": [None, {'country_name': 'Italy'}]}, {"logX__passthrough": [True], "prophetforecaster__log__passthrough": [True], "selection__columns": [[prod_group + ' ADJ'],[prod_group + ' ADJ','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MEAN'],[prod_group + ' ADJ','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MEAN','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MIN','MONTHLY_ROLLING_MAX']], "prophetforecaster__prophet__seasonality_mode": ['additive','multiplicative'], "prophetforecaster__prophet__add_country_holidays": [None, {'country_name': 'Italy'}]}] gscv_prophet = ForecastingGridSearchCV( forecaster = pipe_prophet, cv=cv, param_grid=param_grid, verbose = 1 ) gscv_prophet.fit(train_model, X = df_ex_train, fh = fh) ```

body: FYI @anthonygiorgio97, moved one of the unresolved bugs to a new issue.
I will take a look at this bug!

### Cause of the bug: 

I have found the cause of this bug.  It is coming from the use of `Differencer` with `drop_na = True`. 

This setup means that `X` ends up being shortened by `sum(lags)` (`lags` is a variable in `Differencer`, ie to see an example with lags = [1], you run into the issue where [a, b, c, d] gives [?, b-a, c-b, d-c], and with these params `?` just gets dropped).   But by being shortened `X` causes some issues downstream. 

To see this, neither of these versions of the pipeline raise the error:

```
pipe = TransformedTargetForecaster(steps = [
            ("log", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
            ("differencer", Differencer(na_handling = "fill_zero")),
            ("scaler", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
            ("myforecasterpipe", ForecastingPipeline(steps = [
                ("logX", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
                ("differencerX", Differencer(na_handling = "fill_zero")),
                ("scalerX", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
                ("myforecaster", make_reduction(SVR()))
        ]))  
])
```
```
pipe = TransformedTargetForecaster(steps = [
            ("log", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
            ("scaler", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
            ("myforecasterpipe", ForecastingPipeline(steps = [
                ("logX", OptionalPassthrough(LogTransformer())),
                ("scalerX", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
                ("myforecaster", make_reduction(SVR()))
        ]))  
])
```
Fun side note - the error isn't raised in the case `fh = [1,2]` because in this case `X` ends up being a 1D array, and python allows you to use it to overwrite 2 columns simultaneously, ie we are in the case where we are trying to set `(1,5,2) = (5,1)`.  So I would say that it is still broken in this case even though we don't get the error. 

### What to do next:

One idea I had, was that if `Differencer` (or another transformer that shortens `X` is in a pipeline) then the shape of `X` should be increased prior to running predict to account for the columns that will be lost. (ie, I think the way it works now is that `X` is based on `fh`, but maybe we could try to change it so that it is `fh + num cols lost` or something similar.  That would help ensure that `X` ends up being the correct length at the end of the pipeline for the final prediction.   Open to other suggestions as well though!

Ah, interesting!

The original thread produced a similar bug:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2452
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2487

In 0.13.0, the default of the `na_handling` param will change to `fill_zero`.

> That would help ensure that X ends up being the correct length at the end of the pipeline for the final prediction. 

I think the differencer is already doing that, the problem occurs in cases where there is no earlier time stamps to widen to. If you do backfilling, the result would be the same as `fill_zero`.

Having read the above, I'm not sure what the best action is. `fill_zero` default prevents the condition from materializing, but if the user chooses to shorten the `X`, the error message is not informative.

Questions one might ask:
* is an action necessary at all? E.g., should a user know that the `Differencer` shortens series?
* The `Differencer` docstring could be improved with a warning that certain parameter settings shorten the series, others create NA (and pipelining with an `Imputer` may be advised)
* if a generic error message about index incompatibility should be raised, where should it be raised? Could be a warning along the lines of "transformer A does not guarantee same indices as output, but forecaster B requires same index set as input"?

> I think the differencer is already doing that, the problem occurs in cases where there is no earlier time stamps to widen to. If you do backfilling, the result would be the same as fill_zero.

I guess it might be worth verifying that this works properly in the context of a pipeline or something as well?  For example - if `Differencer` is the third step in a transformer pipeline then we would want to grab the extra points for backfilling before the first step so they get properly transformed.

>if a generic error message about index incompatibility should be raised, where should it be raised? Could be a warning along the lines of "transformer A does not guarantee same indices as output, but forecaster B requires same index set as input"?

Actually broader question related to this - is there a reason `sktime` doesn't make broader use of the `logging` class? This seems like it *could* be an appropriate time to log a warning, and then if there is some sort of error, I *think* the relevant warning (and tips) would print out with the error trace?

> For example - if `Differencer` is the third step in a transformer pipeline then we would want to grab the extra points for backfilling before the first step so they get properly transformed.

Good point. Though, I can't see a way for this without "contextual awareness" of estimator, i.e., the `Differencer` being aware that it's being called within a pipeline and what the other steps are. Contextual awareness of estimators is imo one of many pathways to hell, can you think of a way that would not require it?

>Actually broader question related to this - is there a reason `sktime` doesn't make broader use of the `logging` class? 

I think it's a combination of laziness and lack of developer familiarity (e.g., I would think I have only beginner familiarity with `logging`).

With the "plumbing" layer in place, we could localize logging concerns there? Any good ideas, e.g., how a design might look like, and how it would materialize in this specific example?

Re this very bug: do you think it's solved by the changes to `Differencer` parameters, or is more action needed?

>Good point. Though, I can't see a way for this without "contextual awareness" of estimator, i.e., the Differencer being aware that it's being called within a pipeline and what the other steps are. Contextual awareness of estimators is imo one of many pathways to hell, can you think of a way that would not require it?

I totally agree! I think my plan was not to make `Differencer` contextually away but pipelines!  ie - pipelines are aware of all the steps and *in theory* should be able to count the number of lost columns and adjust the input accordingly.  To me this seems like it could be an appropriate place to do so, then we could encourage anyone chaining together transformers/forecasters to use the pipelining features.  Or we go the `pywatts` route which is closer to everything is a pipeline? (even if just one step?)

> Re this very bug: do you think it's solved by the changes to Differencer parameters, or is more action needed?

I think it is "solved" by no longer raising errors, but I suspect statistically it might not be doing what the original author intended... (due to the issues above) so I would potentially be hesitant to mark it as fully solved.  I have a potential workaround in mind that might not require changing the code base (but is in-elegant) by just splitting the pipeline into 2 parts - a transformer-style pipeline that reduces the dimension by 1 (ie starts out with fh one larger) and then feeding the output of that pipeline into a `TransformedTargetForecaster` which has the remainder of the original steps. Would need to check that it actually works before posting it as a solution. 

As to logging, I think Lukasz has an example of what that might look like in sktime in his PR #2744. For this example I was thinking about logging a warning when the user uses the `drop_na` option that it might raise issues.  The idea would be to create a more informative error trace if there are issues down the road from making that choice

>pipelines are aware of all the steps and in theory should be able to count the number of lost columns and adjust the input accordingly.

If that's the plan, then the components need to be able to tell the pipeline what the expected output *size* is, not just the format. E.g., "which columns will you lose"?
I was already thinking about giving transformers a method such as `get_expected_cols(X)` or similar, and one could have `get_expected_rows`, although I wonder whether it really adds sth above simply passing `X` to `transform` and looking at what comes out.

>I have a potential workaround in mind that might not require changing the code base (but is in-elegant) by just splitting the pipeline into 2 parts - a transformer-style pipeline that reduces the dimension by 1 (ie starts out with fh one larger) and then feeding the output of that pipeline into a TransformedTargetForecaster which has the remainder of the original steps. Would need to check that it actually works before posting it as a solution.

I don't understand the proposed solution here. You would have some transformers separate? Based on what would we split the transformer chain? Can you explain? Perhaps also in one of the meetings, since it seems involved.

>As to logging, I think Lukasz has an example of what that might look like in sktime in his PR https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2744. For this example I was thinking about logging a warning when the user uses the drop_na option that it might raise issues. The idea would be to create a more informative error trace if there are issues down the road from making that choice

Maybe it's also worth looking at the mock estimator(s) of @ltsaprounis which already log method calls?

issue.title: [BUG] loosen index check related tags and fix incorrect pipeline tag inference

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR loosens checks related to index equality related tags:

* if a forecaster has `"X-y-must-have-same-index"` and `"ignores-exogeneous-X"` tag both set to True, this will no longer result in an exception if `X` is passed and is not index compliant with `y`. Why: if `X` is ignored, then `X.index` should also not matter for anything, including checks.
* In transformer and forecaster pipelines, the `"X-y-must-have-same-index"` tag is no longer copied from forecaster or conjunction-inferred from transformers. This was logically incorrect, as there are transformers that can add or remove indices. There have been actual instances of unexpected behaviour around this in pipelines. Example 1: `Aggregator` which adds indices https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2711; example 2: `Differencer` which removes indices https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2807, https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2452
(FYI @ngupta23, @anthonygiorgio97)
* if a forecaster has `"ignores-exogeneous-X"`, then `X=None` is passed to the inner methods, instead of performing unnecessary conversions on `X` and passing the result to the inner methods. This is done after performing input checks on `X`, to let the user know early of non-conformant `X` - even if `X` is never used.

The PR also adds two tests that ensure that the ablated examples from https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2711 run.

issue.title: [ENH] Design Discussion around pipelines and transformers which change element size.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Related to issue #2807, and potentially also #2806 and #2879. 

I think we might be able to solve some of these problems by not treating the pipeline object as a forecaster until the very last step.

More broadly, I think this might be an argument in favor of making the pipelines themselves more modular.  

Just opening this issues to kick off the discussion and connect related issues.

body:
So, I wanted to follow up on this issue, both to propose a solution to this specific problem, and to move the design questions which have come up as a result of this issue to a new more design-focused issue (#2880). 

First, here is a proposed solution which works with our current code base.  Essentially one can pre-transform the data for all the steps up to and including the one which changes size.  Then you can continue with the rest of the pipeline as before.  One disadvantage of this solution is that it makes it harder to automate either including or not including the `Log-Transformer` with `OptionalPassthrough`  In the meantime I suggest the original user who raised this issue compare the best solutions available both with and without that transformer manually.  (and hopefully we will arrive at a cleaner solution soon)

```
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction, ForecastingPipeline, TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import ExpandingWindowSplitter, temporal_train_test_split, ForecastingGridSearchCV
from sktime.forecasting.fbprophet import Prophet
from sktime.transformations.series.adapt import TabularToSeriesAdaptor
from sktime.transformations.series.boxcox import LogTransformer
from sktime.transformations.series.compose import OptionalPassthrough
from sktime.transformations.series.difference import Differencer
from sktime.transformations.compose import TransformerPipeline
from sklearn import clone

from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.svm import SVR
from sktime.datasets import load_longley

y, X = load_longley()

#split train/test both y and X
fh = [1,2,3,4]
train_model, test_model = temporal_train_test_split(y, fh = fh)
X_train = X[X.index.isin(train_model.index)]
X_test = X[X.index.isin(test_model.index)]

#preprocess the steps
pre_process_steps = [
    LogTransformer(),
    Differencer(),
]

y_transformed = train_model
X_transformed = X_train
for transformer in pre_process_steps:
    y_transformed = clone(transformer).fit_transform(X=y_transformed)
    X_transformed = clone(transformer).fit_transform(X=X_transformed)

#pipeline
pipe = TransformedTargetForecaster(steps = [
            ("scaler", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
            ("myforecasterpipe", ForecastingPipeline(steps = [
                ("scalerX", TabularToSeriesAdaptor(StandardScaler())),
                ("myforecaster", make_reduction(SVR()))
        ]))  
])

#cv setup
N_cv_fold = 1
step_cv = 1
cv = ExpandingWindowSplitter(initial_window = len(y_transformed) - (N_cv_fold - 1) * step_cv - len(fh),
                            start_with_window = True,
                            step_length = step_cv,
                            fh = fh)

param_grid = [{"myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__window_length": [2,3],
               "myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__estimator__C": [10,100]
              },
              {"myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__window_length": [2,3],
               "myforecasterpipe__myforecaster__estimator__C": [10,100]
              }
             ]

#grid search
gscv = ForecastingGridSearchCV(
            forecaster = pipe,
            cv=cv,
            param_grid=param_grid,
            verbose = 1
        )

#fit
gscv.fit(y_transformed, X = X_transformed)
```
As to more design minded questions - we are moving that discussion to a new issue (#2880), however in the meantime I suspect one reasonable solution may be that even though we are using these pipelines as forecasters, we might not actually need to trim X for the actual forecasting step until the final step which actually performs the forecasting?
@fkiraly, if you agree that the above solution is reasonable, maybe we can close this issue?

> we might not actually need to trim X for the actual forecasting step until the final step which actually performs the forecasting?

Hm, not sure - I thought the issue is not so much with `X` being *trimmed* but being *transformed* into sth with a different index set. Where there is not a clear "not trimmed" option, since the result is not simply `X` at some sub-set of columns.

I also think applying transformations separately is not a conclusive solution, only a temporary workaround. This does not tune the transformation steps together with the rest, and for interface conformance you want everything to be an estimator.

So, I would not want to close this with that as the final word.

Are there any candidate solutions that we could look at?
